blocks.text: NoSQL databases are non-relational, designed for flexible schemas and massive-scale data. They are widely used for Big Data, real-time analytics, and distributed systems.

list: Document-Based: Stores data in JSON-like documents (e.g., MongoDB).
Key-Value: Stores data as key-value pairs for fast lookup (e.g., Redis).
Column-Based: Stores data by columns instead of rows for analytics (e.g., Cassandra).
Graph-Based: Stores data as nodes and edges for relationships (e.g., Neo4j).

image.caption: Common NoSQL database types and their use cases.

blocks.text: NoSQL databases offer horizontal scalability, high availability, and schema flexibility, which are crucial for web-scale applications.

blocks.title: Example Use Case
blocks.text: Social media platforms use document-based and graph databases to store user posts, relationships, and interactions efficiently.
